Japanese fisherman found a robe made of white feathers on the beach. It belonged to a beautiful woman swimming in the sea. She said she would sing him a song if he returned her robe, for without it she could not go home. He did so and she sang him a hymn to the moon, where she lived, and as she sang her feathered robe became vast white wings, which carried her to her lunar palace.The moon is often considered female, as are the gods who represented it in ancient times. According to the astrologer and occultist Bruce King, who was born in Chicago in 1897 and wrote under the name Zolar:&nbsp“In mythologies worldwide, rulers of the moon are female deities.”Huge, unexplained ‘mass’ spotted under the MoonIn his Encyclopedia of Signs, Omens and Superstitions he lists many of them: “For the Canaanites, the name of the moon goddess was Jerah (for who the city of Jericho was named). For Egyptians, Isis and Hathor were associated with the moon. For the Babylonians, the goddess Ishtar was given similar honours.For the Greeks, Artemis&nbspand Diana&nbsp(hunting goddesses), were both&nbspconnected with the moon as well. Hence, it was not surprising that in medieval Europe, Diana became the patroness of witches, since she already ruled “horned”&nbspanimals such as the stag and goat.Witches, of course, meet by moonlight. Shakespeare’s three witches, or weird sisters, in Macbeth, when cooking up their cooking up their “toil and trouble” in their boiling cauldron, throw in “slips of yew silver’d in the moon’s eclipse”. They are visited by Hecate, the goddess of witchcraft, associated with the moon.Brewer’s Book of Myth and Legend, edited by JC Cooper, tells us that Hecate was the name the Greeks gave to the moon before she had fully risen and after she had set hidden, occult. A crescent moon was identified as Astarte, as Diana or Cynthia when full. The&nbspancients personified the moon as Selene, who fell in love with Endymion, a shepherd, who was put into an immortal sleep by a jealous Zeus.The moon is for lovers, immortalised as such in song:&nbsp“Blue Moon”&nbsp“Give Me The Moonlight”&nbspBeethoven’s Moonlight Sonata. The moon has illuminated lovers’ trysts and in Brazil they say you are only truly in love if you can easily make out the rabbit in the moon, a piece of Chinese-originated folklore that identifies the markings on the face of the full moon as a rabbit.Just as the moon controls the tides of the sea, so it is connected to the bodies of women. In many folk legends, says Zolar:&nbsp“Girls are warned not to stare at the moon or lay in moonlight, or they will be impregnated by the moon and give birth to some kind of monster.”Is there any truth in the old stories that women’s menstrual cycles are linked directly to the moon? The Uaupe tribe of the Amazon refer to a girl’s first menstruation as “defloration by the moon”. The word menstruation is derived from the Latin word menses, meaning “monthly”, and the Greek “mene”, referring to the moon. Science perhaps doesn’t back that up, other than through coincidence the average menstrual cycle is 29 days, the lunar cycle is 29.5 days.Nasa to send spacecraft to Saturn’s moon TitanNasa to open moon rock samples sealed since Apollo missionsElon Musk tweets ‘Occupy Mars’ alongside photo of the MoonAliens could be living on other moons, scientists sayThe moon, of course, only comes out at night...&nbspexcept when it doesn’t. Sometimes we see the pale ghost of the moon in the bright blue sky, because of the passage of the moon around the Earth and, as it gets closer to being a new moon, and at its nearest relative point to the sun, we sometimes see the solar reflection off&nbspthe moon’s surface in broad daylight.But it is generally the dark velvet of the night sky the moon inhabits, which gives it its associations with the occult, and secret things. Charles Walker, in his Encyclopedia of Secret Knowledge, says:&nbsp“The moon is the symbol of the imaginative, reflective, interiorising power in our world. In astrology and alchemy, the moon is an index of the withdrawal principle, and of the subconscious or hidden side of life.”Moonlight is for lovers, but dark deeds are carried out by the silvery glow, as well. The term moonraker is from an old Wiltshire folk tale, about locals who were dredging a pond for kegs of smuggled alcohol. When confronted by the excise men, they played the dumb yokels and said they were trying to rake out the moon’s reflection in the water.&nbspIf you are planning a robbery, then don’t do it on the third day of a new moon, or the enterprise will end in disaster, according to an old proverb. If you fall ill on the eighth day of a new moon, it’s likely death will follow. Should someone die at the time of a new moon, three more deaths are said to be on the horizon. And sleeping with the moon shining on your face will result in distortion of your features, or insanity.Ah, the moon and the mind. The insane were called called “lunatics” for a reason...&nbsptheir state of mind was said to be directly influenced by the phases of the moon. The Lunacy Act of 1845 defined a lunatic as a person who exhibited lucidity in the first two phases of the moon but grew demented during the full moon phase. In 1940 a soldier, charged with murder, pleaded “moon madness” in mitigation in court.Lunacy, and the changes it wrought in humans, brings us back to the man who is pure of heart, and says his prayers by night, yet becomes a wolf. The ditty might have been penned by Curt Siodmak for The Wolf Man, but he was building on a dark tradition that has its roots in classical mythology.Zolar has little truck with the modern portrayal of lycanthropy, commenting somewhat huffily:&nbsp“Just like vampires, the werewolf has been glorified by Hollywood and the motion pictures. For the ancients, a werewolf was a person transformed into a wolf by magical means. It is said that werewolves roamed the country at night and would attack babies and humans.”Murder case where man ‘thought victim was werewolf’ ends in mistrialThere are defences, of course, and ways to spot a werewolf in human form. They have flat fingers, so they used to say, and hair covering the palms of their&nbsphands. And, of course, though werewolves were said to be immune to normal ordnance, a silver bullet, especially if blessed by a priest, would kill one. If that seems extreme –&nbspfor example if the werewolf is a loved one –&nbspsaying their Christian name three times would effect a transformation back into human form.It is said that the first man-to-wolf transformation was at the hands of Zeus, who was somewhat appalled that Lycaon of Arcadia&nbspsacrificed his own child to the ruler of Olympus. Zeus turned Lycaon into a wolf for his crime, which is where we get the term lycanthrope from to denote a werewolf.According to John and Caitlin Matthews’&nbspElement Encyclopedia of Magical Creatures, there was a wolf-cult built around Zeus after this, which survived until at least the first century AD. They write:&nbsp“A member of the Antaeus family told Pliny the Elder that he had been a lycanthrope for nine years, having drawn lots with the rest of his clan to partake in these secret rites.”A werewolf could be created through being cursed, perhaps by a Hecate-worshipping witch, or sleeping in the light of the moon, or being conceived under a new moon. Or, as in the movies, from The Wolf Man to An American Werewolf in London (in which bluff rural Yorkshireman Brian Glover exhorts a couple of naive American tourists to “Beware the moon!”, to no avail), being bitten by another werewolf.Werewolf mania perhaps reached its height in 16th-century France, when dozens of people were tried and executed for being werewolves in a frenzy that spread across Europe, a full&nbspcentury before the Salem witch trials in the United States.Michel Verdun is thought to be the first man to be tried for lycanthropy, in Poligny in 1521. Authorities investigating a wolf attack followed a trail of evidence and supposition that led them to Verdun’s home. He was arrested and under torture confessed to being a werewolf, pointing the finger at two other men, Pierre Bourgot and Philibert Montot.Bourgot told the authorities that he had been approached by three men dressed in black who urged him to reject God, and in return he was promised protection for his flock of sheep and given an ointment which, when applied, allowed him to transform into a wolf by the light of the moon. All three men were executed. Similar trials were carried out across Germany, the Netherlands and Estonia.We now know, of course, that the moon is not imbued with any magical powers, nor can exert any kind of influence over us. It is a lump of rock, about 2,000 miles in diameter.&nbspIt is about&nbsp4.5 billion years old, and is 250,000 miles away from the Earth. It has little atmosphere, and no weather no erosion means that the footprints left by the crew of Apollo 11 half a century ago will endure, untouched, for millions of years.And yet… the moon fascinates us beyond the fact of us actually getting there in 1969. The full moon carries with it far more weight than a mere satellite reflecting the light of the sun, it shoulders mythology, legend and folklore that dates back almost as far as mankind itself.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsStreaming service loses members in its biggest market for first time in eight years, prompting fears that competition from rivals Disney, Apple and Amazon is beginning to biteClick to followThe IndependentMore than $18bn (£14.5m) was wiped off the stock market value of Netflix overnight on Wednesday after subscriber numbers fell in the US for the first time in eight years.Worldwide, Netflix&nbspadded 2.7 million subscribers between April and June, little more than half of the 5 million it had forecast, sending shares plunging 12 per cent in after-hours trading.In the US, Netflix’s biggest market, subscriber numbers slipped to 60.1 million at the end of the quarter from 60.2 million in the previous period.Netflix is still the dominant video-on-demand service with 151.6 million subscribers worldwide at the end of June, but rivals such as Amazon&nbspand Hulu have been investing heavily to compete.Disney, which has an unrivalled back catalogue of films and television shows, is also ramping up its push into the streaming market and Apple launched its own service in March.Created with Sketch.Hidden gems: The best Netflix originals you might have missed Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.120 Money Heist (TV series, one season, 2017–)Known as La Casa de Papel (House of Paper) in its native Spanish, Money Heist is Netflix’s most streamed non-English language show. The bank heist is a tired dramatic trope these days, but don’t let that, or the show’s bland English-language title, put you off – creator Álex Pina has made something special. The heist here, led by a mysterious man known only as The Professor, involves breaking into the Royal Mint of Spain and printing off €2.4 billion. There are even more twists in the show’s 15 episodes than there are hostages. 220 American Vandal (TV series, two seasons, 2017–2018)Part satire of true crime documentaries such as Making a Murderer, part carefully observed portrayal of teenage life, American Vandal was criminally underappreciated during its two season run. It’s been cancelled now, but that doesn’t mean you can’t catch up with it, and then write Netflix a strongly worded email.320 One Day at a Time (TV series, two seasons, 2017–)In stark contrast to the off-beat, low-key comedy that currently rules TV – the kind that provokes a wry smirk rather than a hearty laugh – One Day at a Time is a big, bright sitcom filmed in front of an interminably enthusiastic studio audience. You wouldn’t have thought that the story of a Cuban-American army veteran  nurse  single mother – who suffers from PTSD and depression – would fit into this format, but it does so beautifully, tackling issues of sexuality, racism and sexism in the process.  Based on writer  director Tamara Jenkins’s own fertility struggles, Private Life stars Kathryn Hahn and Paul Giamatti (both giving brilliant performances) as a spiky, loving middle-aged couple desperate to have a baby. They even rope their enthusiastic but irresponsible niece Sadie (Kayli Carter) into the mix, much to the horror of Sadie’s mother (Molly Shannon, turning a potentially repellent character into one worthy of empathy). It’s subtle, restrained and beautifully realised.520 Big Mouth (TV series, two seasons, 2017–)Crude, rude, and rife with surprise emissions and bodily functions, animated sitcom Big Mouth is also a sensitive, nuanced deep e into the various horrors of teenagehood. When 12-year-old Andrew Glouberman (John Mulaney) is visited by the hormone monster (Nick Kroll, who voices many of the show’s best characters), he finds his life irreversibly – and seemingly disastrously – changed. Unlike many other puberty-centred comedies, Big Mouth makes as much time for its confused female protagonists as its male ones Maya Rudolph is a delight as the female hormone monster, and look out for Kristen Wiig’s wonderful turn as a talking vagina.  620 Easy (TV series, two seasons, 2016–)Joe Swanberg’s style of defiantly undramatic mumblecore isn’t for everyone, but if you enjoyed his earlier films, Drinking Buddies and Happy Christmas, you’ll find plenty to admire in this anthology comedy-drama series. Big-name stars such as Orlando Bloom and Aubrey Plaza crop up, but Jane Adams – who you might remember from Todd Solondz’s chronically depressing 1998 film Happiness – is the show’s heart, and Marc Maron is its jaded soul.Community’s Gillian Jacobs is brilliant as the prickly, magnetic recovering addict Mickey, who forms an unlikely – and arguably deeply unwise – relationship with her nerdy neighbour Gus (Paul Rust). Despite Gus’s pathological need to be the nice guy, we’re never quite sure who or what we’re rooting for – which is what makes Love such complex, compelling viewing.  In 2016, comedian Patton Oswalt’s wife, the true crime writer Michelle McNamara, died suddenly in her sleep. That subject matter doesn’t exactly scream “stand-up special”, but out of his devastating loss, Oswalt managed to craft something funny and profound. Over the course of an hour, he processes his grief onstage, managing to find humour in the struggle to raise his grieving six-year-old daughter alone.920 Santa Clarita Diet (TV series, two seasons, 2017–)Granted, this horror-comedy – which stars Drew Barrymore as a neurotic real estate agent who suddenly develops a taste for human flesh – is really silly, and really, really disgusting. But it’s also strangely charming, and funny. Timothy Olyphant is excellent as Sheila’s frazzled husband Joel, and the pair’s idiosyncratic but respectful relationship with their smart teenage daughter Abby (Liv Hewson) isn’t quite like anything else on TV right now.1020 Dark Tourist (TV series, one season, 2018–)New Zealand journalist David Farrier is an unlikely TV presenter in the same way that Louis Theroux is – in just about every scenario in which he finds himself, he’s a little bit awkward. But as with Theroux, Farrier’s weakness is actually his strength, allowing him to endear himself to the many unusual people he meets on his journey through the world’s most questionable tourist destinations. Farrier’s stops include the site of the Fukushima nuclear disaster, the road where JFK was assassinated, and the Milwaukee suburbs where serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer murdered his victims.1120 Sacred Games (TV series, one season, 2018–)Based on Vikram Chandra’s epic 2006 novel, Netflix’s first Indian original series is a slowly unfolding gem. The first season of Sacred Games – which follows a troubled police officer (Saif Ali Khan) who has 25 days to save his city thanks to a tip-off from a presumed dead gangster – only covered one quarter of Chandra’s 1,000-page novel. As the show itself declared when it announced the forthcoming second season, “the worst is yet to come”.When the trailer for Dumplin’ first landed, it seemed all the ingredients were in place for a film that was at worst tone-deaf, and at best vaguely patronising. Thank heavens, then, that the trailer did Dumplin’ such a disservice. Starring Danielle Macdonald (who broke out in the excellent 2017 film Patti Cake$) as Willowdean, a self-described “fat girl” who enters a local pageant to annoy her former beauty queen mother (Jennifer Aniston), Dumplin’ is as funny, warm and sensitive as its protagonist – and with a killer Dolly Parton-laden soundtrack to boot.1320 Dark (TV series, one season, 2017–)This sci-fi thriller – which features disappearing children, a mysterious local power plant, and scenes set in the Eighties – has, for obvious reasons, drawn comparisons to Stranger Things. But Dark is even more beguiling and (true to its name) less family-friendly than Stranger Things.1420 The Death and Life of Marsha P Johnson (Film, 2017)Though it’s been somewhat tarnished by claims that director David France appropriated the work and research of trans film-maker Reina Gossett, this documentary is nonetheless a loving, respectful tribute to gay rights activist Marsha P Johnson. One of the key figures in the Stonewall uprising (though her involvement was almost entirely eradicated in 2015’s critically hated Stonewall), Johnson modelled for Andy Warhol, performed onstage with drag group Hot Peaches, helped found the Gay Liberation Front, and then died under suspicious circumstances in 1992.1520 On My Block (TV series, one season, 2018–)This coming-of-age series might not have found as many eyeballs as it deserved last year, but those it did find were glued to the screen. In fact, it was the most-binged show of 2018 – meaning that it had the highest watch-time-per-viewing session of any Netflix original. Set It Up is responsible not only for coining the term “over-dicking” (it’s much more innocent than it sounds), but for rejuvenating a tired genre.Martin Freeman stars as the father struggling to protect his young daughter from a zombie epidemic spreading across Australia. So far, so overdone. But this drama thriller, directed by Ben Howling and Yolanda Ramke and based on their 2013 short of the same name, throws a handful of unpredictable ners in the works.    1920 Godless (TV series, one season, 2017–)With shades of John Ford's The Searchers, this languorous western was critically acclaimed but swiftly forgotten after it landed on Netflix in 2016. Set in 1884, it's about Frank Griffin (Jeff Daniels) and his notoriously ruthless gang of outlaws’ pursuit of their injured former ally Roy Goode (Jack O’Connell), who is hiding out in a small town populated solely by women after a mining accident killed off all its men. A gun-toting Michelle Dockery, clearly relishing the change of scenery after years of Downton Abbey, and a taciturn Jack O’Connell, are on brilliant form.2020 Atypical (TV series, two seasons, 2017–)This coming-of-age series about a teenage boy with autism was sweet and well-intentioned from the start, but its first season was criticised for a handful of inaccuracies, and for its lack of autistic actors. title: pound dollar exchange rate latest sterling uk us brexit irish backstop euro
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCurrency extends losses, nearing parity with euro, after Johnson’s and Hunt’s remarks fan fears of no-deal BrexitClick to followThe IndependentThe pound has slipped further from a 27-month low against the dollar reached earlier and slid to a new six-month low against the euro.&nbspThe embattled currency tumbled on Tuesday after the two contenders to be Britain's next prime minister promised to scrap the Irish backstop – a key part of Theresa May’s Brexit agreement – amplifying fears of a no-deal Brexit.Stronger dollar pressured the exchange rate further on Wednesday, with the pound last trading at $1.2407. Sterling is nearing parity with the euro, with one pound now buying 1.1056&nbspeuro.Since the start of 2016, the pound has lost 15 per cent of its value against a basket of currencies that includes the dollar and the euro.Fears that Britain will crash out of the EU rose further on Tuesday after news emerged that Boris Johnson could send MPs home for up to two weeks in October if he becomes prime minister – a move that could prevent them stopping a no-deal Brexit.Both Johnson and his rival Jeremy Hunt had already refused to rule out a no-deal Brexit.&nbspThe weaker exchange rate will be felt keenly by people heading off on summer holidays abroad.&nbspAnalysis by Post Office Travel Money found that the pound has also declined against a number of other currencies used in popular destinations compared with this time last year, such as Thailand, Bali, Japan and Barbados. However,&nbspsterling has appreciated against currencies used in Turkey, Iceland and South Africa.Additional reporting by agenciesOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: ben nevis banana skins mountain litter rubbish three peaks
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options‘People genuinely think that because it’s natural everything will be hunky-dory,’ says climbing groupClick to followThe IndependentHill-walkers have been urged not to drop banana skins on the UK’s highest peak after several kilograms of waste were found in just days.&nbspBen Nevis is strewn with litter largely made up of fruit peel and tissues, according to mountaineering groups.&nbspThe owner of one expedition company found&nbsp8kg of banana skins in just two days last week.“Ben Nevis has particular problems with litter of all sorts because it’s so popular, and because so many of those who climb it aren’t regular hill-goers and don’t seem to appreciate the harm they are doing by leaving litter, whether it’s plastic or banana peels,” Mountaineering Scotland&nbspsaid in a statement.Neil Reid, a spokesman for the group, told&nbspThe Independent: “A lot of people quite genuinely think that because a banana or orange or apple or whatever is natural, it will just rot down into the environment and everything will be hunky-dory.Created with Sketch.Litter on Ben Nevis Show all 7Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.4kg of banana skins found in a single day on Ben NevisLitter found on Ben Nevis by Mountaineering ScotlandGraffiti on a rock on Ben NevisA view of Fort William from the upper slopes of Ben NevisLitter collected on the Ben Nevis trail by Mountaineering ScotlandBananas collected on the Ben Nevis trailA view of Ben Nevis4kg of banana skins found in a single day on Ben NevisLitter found on Ben Nevis by Mountaineering ScotlandGraffiti on a rock on Ben NevisA view of Fort William from the upper slopes of Ben NevisLitter collected on the Ben Nevis trail by Mountaineering ScotlandBananas collected on the Ben Nevis trailA view of Ben NevisBanana skins can take&nbspyears to decompose at altitude, Mr Reid added.Ben Nevis, at 1,345m, is the UK’s highest mountain, attracting an estimated 100,000 climbers a year and thousands more to the wider area.Rich Pyne, who founded the Real3Peaks Challenge campaign to clean up the UK’s best-known mountains, said volunteers had&nbsprid the Scottish icon of hundreds of kilograms of rubbish over several years, including 135kg in 2018 alone – though that figure was down from 230kg in 2013.In a Facebook post last week,&nbsphe said he found&nbsp8kg of banana peel in just two days on Ben Nevis.&nbsp“It’s a never ending story,” he wrote.&nbspTurquoise lake loved by Instagrammers turns out to be toxic waste dumpHe told&nbspThe Independent: “Most of the debris I notice in the hills is stuff that has been wedged between rocks, or often stashed&nbspbehind summits. Anything that is hidden in such a way suggests that the person leaving it behind is most definitely aware that it is not the correct way to dispose of their rubbish.“You don’t actually see people just dropping litter these days, they all know better.&nbspSome have suggested adding bins to the hills, but this does encourage folk&nbspto empty their pockets, and leave even more behind.“Pistachio shells make a regular appearance on the Ben, as well as cigarette ends. All litter is bad, but has different impacts. Plastic will never go away, foodstuff&nbspcan poison the wildlife, and tissuesfaeces spread bacteria.”First-time climbers&nbspcan be the worst offenders, Mr Pyne said, likely through ignorance regarding how long organic material takes to break down in a mountain environment a banana skin may take between two and three years to disappear.However, following the Real3Peaks organised litter-picks and the long-term work of other volunteers, “the noticeable volume has gone down, and the place is looking much better for it”, he said.A more pressing problem is walkers going to the toilet because the desire for privacy leads them to pick the same spots over and over again, he said. “Most or all of the accessible and obvious hiding places&nbspare open, unflushed toilets, smelling very bad, often draped in used tissues, a vibrant green algae present, and black coloured soil, which has been tainted by the concentrated urine.”Staying well away from water courses while doing one’s business is important, Mr Pyne said.He added: “The best thing that anyone outdoors can do, whether in the park, down by the canal, or in the mountains, is to pick up litter they see, and be considerate of where they will ‘go’.”The next Real3Peaks Challenge is due to take place on 12 October.Mountaineering Scotland runs a #TakItHame campaign designed to encourage walkers to pick up any litter they see.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options‘Perhaps I am being a bit harsh, but it’s about time we became a bit harsh,’ says&nbspFrans TimmermansClick to followIndy PoliticsA top EU official has accused the UK’s Brexit negotiators of “running around like idiots”, comparing UK ministers to the hapless characters from classic TV sitcom&nbspDad’s Army.Frans Timmermans, the European Commission’s vice president, said leaders in Brussels believed&nbspBritish ministers would produce “Harry Potter-like” trickery when they began negotiations in 2017.Instead they acted like Lance Corporal Jones from the classic sitcom, Mr Timmermans told BBC’s Panorama programme, set for broadcast on Thursday night.“We thought they are so brilliant that in some vault somewhere in Westminster there will be a Harry Potter-like book with all the tricks and all the things in it to do,” he said. “Then the first time I saw public utterances by David Davis ... I thought: ‘Oh my God they haven’t got a plan’.“That was really shocking frankly because the damage if you don't have a plan … it’s like Lance Corporal Jones you know, ‘Don’t panic, don’t panic’, running around like idiots.”&nbspCreated with Sketch. Show all 5Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The Hunchback of Notre Dame with a Brexit spinA Room with a View of Britain's futureThe Sound of Music reimaginedThe Hunchback of Notre Dame with a Brexit spinA Room with a View of Britain's futureThe Sound of Music reimaginedMr Timmermans also accused Boris Johnson of “playing games” with Brussels when he was foreign secretary. He was not sure Mr Johnson was ever “being genuine” in his approach to the EU and Brexit.“Perhaps I am being a bit harsh, but it’s about time we became a bit harsh,” the European Commission official added.EU warns UK must ‘face the consequences’ of no-deal Brexit – liveEU offered to delay Brexit for five years during secret talksAlso interviewed for the BBC programme, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator&nbspMichel Barnier&nbspsaid the UK “will have to face the consequences” if it crashes out of the union without a deal.Mr Barnier also said the outgoing prime minister Theresa May and her ministers “never” suggested they might opt for a no-deal Brexit during negotiations.He said: “I think that the UK side, which is well informed and competent and knows the way we work on the EU side, knew from the very beginning that we’ve never been impressed by such a threat. It’s not useful to use it.”However, Ms May's official spokesman later insisted: The Prime Minister was clear in her discussions in public or in private that the UK could leave without a deal.The European Commission’s top official&nbspMartin Selmayr, meanwhile, said he thought the UK was still unprepared to leave without a deal.“We have seen what has been prepared on our side of the border for a hard Brexit. We don’t see the same level of preparation on the other side of the border.”The EU secretly offered to put Brexit “on ice” for five years in order to come up with a new deal for Europe, Ms May’s de facto deputy David Lidington told Panorama.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Department of Natural Resources and one of the first organisations that arrived on the scene to help with the rescue.Three of the whales died, including one that had to be euthanised, he said.Do people in Japan actually want commercial whaling to resume?On Wednesday afternoon, harbour pilots located the pod of more than 40 whales in the Brunswick shipping channel. A group from the National Marine Mammal Foundation monitored the whales by boat.“We’re cautiously optimistic that the group dodged a bullet, and that they’re now on their way to deeper water,” said Clay George, a biologist for the Georgia Wildlife Resources Division.Crews had also flown a helicopter above the area, which is about 90 miles south of Savannah, and determined no other whales were stranded.Pilot whales are essentially large dolphins, and can grow to 24 feet in length and weigh 6,600 pounds.Speaking to reporters on Wednesday, Dr George said they were still investigating why the animals rushed to shore, an event he called “exceedingly rare in Georgia”.Dr George described the whales as “one to three-tonne dolphins”.“They’re so social that if one animal in the group gets injured or sick, all the other animals in the group can follow them great distances into shore,” he said, “and then they can strand.”Normally these creatures swim 100 miles offshore, he said, which means “something went wrong”, possibly days or weeks ago.In the necropsy, Dr George said researchers will be looking for ingested plastic, evidence of plastic netting or signs of an acoustic disturbance, like bombs or sonars, that could have caused one or more of the animals to swim towards land.“Tomorrow will be the beginning of a process that could go on for potentially weeks,” he said.Normally, added Dr George, he would not advise humans to intervene with pilot whales, but in this case, “it was the right thing to do”.Dr&nbspErin Fougeres, who administers the marine mammal stranding program for the Fisheries ision of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in the Southeast, said that “mass strandings of pilot whales aren’t entirely uncommon for us.”There have been about 23 mass strandings in southeastern states since 1991, mostly along the Gulf of Mexico, but never in Georgia, she said.“This event, so far, and fingers crossed, has had the best title: sun readers debate boris hunt live
story: Both teams appeared much more relaxed this time around compared to last weeks ITV debate.There were jokes aplenty and both candidates ribbed each other and were well received by the upbeat audience.Boris tripped up a bit over immigration and refused to commit to getting the numbers down.But he did rule out an early election # something which will make many Tories extremely happy.They both attacked Donald Trump over his comments about democratic congresswomen, but refused to call him a racist.And they both agreed to having at least one top woman in their Cabinetthey become PM next week.All in all, both Boris and Hunt did well. Most of them answered the question honestly but had a decent dig at each other as they went.All in all, a very entertaining debate filled with fun # and some news too.In just a week’s time we will know which of these two men will be your next Prime Minister.Thanks to everyone for watching, and our fantastic readers for sending in their questions.We’ll have all the reaction from outside Sun Towers to the debate coming up.And on talkRADIO Ross Kempsell will have all the analysis of the last hour’s debate.And now it’s time for our quick-fire round of questions, to finish off the debate.# climate change target of net zero emissions by  keep it  Boris: YesHunt:Yes# continue to freeze fuel duty, like the last  years Boris: Not making any more spending commitments. I would love to. Not a no! I want to. Hunt: I agree with Boris# Is Jeremy Corbyn personally anti-semitic Hunt: Unfortunately, he may be .Boris: I think by condoning anti-Antisemitism in the way he does, he is effectively culpable of that vice.# when was the last time you cried Hunt: That’s a trick question!Boris: When I came out of Parliament to find my bike had been nicked. I had for all of my mayoral career, a beautul bike. It was never nicked during all my time, I used to ride it everywhere. And barely any time into Sadiq’s reign## will you give England cricket World Cup hero Ben Stokes a knighthood Boris: Dukedoms! We will go to the maximum of what the garter kings allow… Yes!Hunt:Of course.# will you promise to give a job to Boris Hunt Boris: Don’t think it would be right before the end of the campaign to announce any jobs.Hunt: Yes.# Who do you want to win Love Island Boris: I have been watching it very dimly. Seems to involve these people with very few clothes on. Amber  Amber is in Love Island! Does he mean Amber Rudd  Wonder what she thinks of that#.Hunt: I don’t know, I don’t watch it.# will you go for a pint with each other when the contest is over Boris: Several!More houses need to be built, both candidates say.This is a huge issue that young voters keep saying again and again is the best thing to get them back on side#Jeremy Hunt just said he would SCRAP the five-week wait # after Amber Rudd made the case to him.#She has persuaded me that we need to end the five week wait before people can claim UC,# he said. #I think its the right reform but had unintended consequences.#And he said he would look sympathetically at unfreezing benefits.But Boris says hes made enough spending plans.#When it comes to the four year freeze, I think Ive made enough spending commitments for the time being##The Suns been campaigning to end the five week wait and cut it down to help struggling families who have been plunged into debt.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark basu press leaks democracy
story: Police claim to be so overstretched that in some parts of the country they are refusing even to investigate  per cent of reported crimes.Yet at the same time, the politan Police seem quite happy to commit resources to investigate the leaking of diplomatic cables which embarrassed Sir Kim Darroch, who, until his resignation last week, was our man in Washington.Even more bizarrely, the Met has set its Counter Terrorism Command on the operation — yes, the unit that is supposed to spend its time stopping extremists blowing us up. It has threatened journalists, too, that they face prosecutionthey dare to publish the content of the cables.Trying to justy his threats, the Met’s Assistant Commissioner, Neil Basu, said he was sure the leaks had “damaged UK international relations” and on that basis no one publishing the leaks could plead a public interest defence.What a ludicrous over-reaction to what is really no more than a diplomatic spat over the Ferrero Rochers.Sure, it doesn’t exactly help UK US relations when our Ambassador calls the President of the United States “inept” and his administration “uniquely dysal”.But I would say it is mildly less damaging than some of the things that the Leader of Opposition, the Mayor of London and Scotland’s First Minister have said about Donald Trump. I can’t see Mr Basu dangling his handcuffs in front of them — and neither should he.Obviously, Sir Kim has reason to feel aggrieved that someone — presumably in the diplomatic service or the Foreign Office, because there is no evidence of computers being hacked — has leaked information he intended to be private. But it is a matter for the Government to investigate, not the police.How ridiculous Basu has said of the leaker: “You are now also responsible for erting busy detectives from under-taking their core mission.”No, Mr Basu — it is only thanks to your decision that officers have been taken off front-line duties to undertake this investigation.You could have told officials what police officers are forever telling the rest of us when we report our houses broken into or our bikes stolen: Sorry, but we’ve got too much  to do.It would be a dferent mattersomeone had leaked material that really did harm national security.The sort of information leaked by Kim Philby and his Soviet-sympathising accomplices in the s put British lives at risk.But leaking and publishing a diplomat’s private thoughts hardly comes into that category. Mr Basu’s attack on the principles of the free Press echoes Operation Elveden, the failed attempt by the Met to criminalise journalists who had obtained information from police officers, in some cases for money.The Met switched more than  police officers from other duties and arrested  people. The police probe cost taxpayers £.million and yet of  journalists charged, only one was convicted at trial — and that was quashed on appeal. Just one journalist, Dan Evans, pleaded guilty to an Elveden offence and was given a suspended sentence.The prosecutions relied on an ancient offence, Misconduct in Public Office, which was only ever supposed to apply to public servants, not journalists.As many lawyers, including the Lord Chief Justice, pointed out, it simply isn’t a criminal offence for someone to receive or to publish most forms of state information — only for a public official to sell it.There is a very good reason for this. Leaks, and the freedom to put their contents into the public domain, are an essential ingredient of our democracy. It is what helps the Press to keep in check corrupt or over-bearing politicians and public officials.Without the freedom to publish leaked information, for example, we would never have known the extent to which MPs and Lords were abusing their expenses regime.That required a newspaper to publish information gleaned from a computer disk which had been stolen — but thankfully in that case the Met decided that the public interest over-rode a possible offence of handling stolen goods.Without the Panama Papers we would never have known the extent to which wealthy iniduals and corporations have gone into keeping their wealth out of the taxman’s grasp. Without the “climategate” leaks we would not have known how some climate scientists were prepared to manipulate past temperature records to support their theories.It took a leak, too, to establish that the Blair government knew it was unlikely that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, but that George W Bush had resolved to overthrow Saddam regardless.Then there was “Plebgate”, when a leaked police log revealed a bust-up between government chief whip Andrew Mitchell and police manning the gates at Downing Street — and led an officer to be jailed when it was revealed he had invented his witness statement.There are, of course, plenty of other countries in the world where journalists would be locked up for publishing information that has leaked from the government, but they are not countries in which most of us would want to live.By over-reacting to what is an embarrassment to the Foreign Office, the Met has taken a leaf out of the book of President Erdogan of Turkey, who has locked up dozens of journalists as he attempts to suppress all opposition to his regime.Neil Basu and other senior Met Police officers should back off and accept that the Press is quite within its rights to publish leaked information that does not threaten national security.We are, after all, one of the world’s oldest ing democracies — not a tinpot state where people get led off in chains for daring to reveal the truth. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: julio iglesias 3000 lovers
story: But I am responsible for the dubious statistic that has haunted him ever since.My memory ain’t what it used to be, but we met in a hotel room somewhere in London where Julio was promoting something or other, and I had been sent tointerview him for The Sun.But there was one major problem. His English was fairly limited and my Spanish went no further than: “Paella, mucho gracias.”So when, after several minutes of discussing the musical inspiration for his new single album , I went in for the killer question.“How many women have you slept with ”He shrugged.“ ” I ventured.He pulled an expression to suggest I had woefully misjudged his pulling power with the opposite sex. So I aimed higher.“, ”“Ooo knows ” he drawled with a lazy smile. “A gentleman  . . .  he never tell.”“Shall we go with , then ” I suggested, aswe were making a joint entry to one of those “guess how many sweets” attractions at the local fete. He shrugged again, a gesture I took as implicit confirmation. Well, he didn’t deny it.The interview appeared the following day and shortly afterwards the figure went global when the US-based National Enquirer ran with it.Julio, who is charm personied, made no complaint when his legendary Lothario-ism went stratospheric, though many years later he mitigated to another interviewer who broached the subject: “Me, I don’t have numbers. I respect women very much.”Like Mick Jagger, who is said to have bedded around , women, the Spanish crooner joined the ranks of Warren Beatty, Errol Flynn, Jack Nicholson and the notorious lover Casanova as one of history’s great seducers.Back then, such, ahem, swordsmanship was admired. The majority of women swooned at the mere thought of a sacred moment in their seductive gaze, while young men felt both inspired and intimidated by such a dizzyingly high number of sexual conquests.But now  Thanks to the #metoo and #timesup campaigns, men with more notches on their bedposts than the rest of us have had hot dinners are regarded with certain distaste. Last week, Julio’s tongue-in-cheek statistic popped up again, when a -year-old man finally won recognition as the star’s son — the product of a brief affair in the s.Suddenly, the legendary “,” was being viewed through the modern-day, more puritanical prism, where such behaviour might be regarded as “sex addiction”.Whatever the truth , he’s now been with we Miranda Rijnsburger for more than  years and they have five children.So it’s fair to say that his womanising days are long gone. Just as well, perhaps. Because,the Love Island men are anything to go by, old roues are now old hat and it’s romantic and wholly faithful young men like Tommy Fury who, quite rightly, earn the nation’s admiration. Long may it go on.Though it seems there are still some lotharios refusing to go quietly. Last year, Italian playboy Maurizio Zanfanti,  — dubbed the “Romeo of Rimini” after claiming to have slept with , women — died while having sex with a -year-old tourist in his car. It’s what he would have wanted.JOBLESS Daniel Eyers and his pregnant partner Lucrezia Worrell say they have been evicted from their Kent council house for spending their rent money on takeaways.The couple, who have four children, are now living with Daniel’s mum. Daniel, , says: “I can’t get a job as it would mean my children would miss out on school, as I have to drive them there every day.”Oh let me count the ways.A flexible, part-time job perhaps  How about your partner taking them to school, or asking other parents for a lt  Or perhaps desisting from having a fth childyou can’t afford to keep the other four Meanwhile, let us compare and contrast this “can’t do” attitude with that of this father in Vietnam who drags his son across a raging, muddy river in a plastic bag so he can get to school, before ing to his remote village to work.A couple of years ago, we cowered inside a friend’s French holiday home as hailstones the size of golf balls rained down outside.Oh how we laughed . . . until I remembered our hire car parked outside.It was peppered with more dents than a Swiss cheese and, because we hadn’t taken out the “full insurance”, left us with a bill that cost more than the actual holiday.A BRIEF chat in front of the assembled cameras at Wimbledon was all it took for the Duchesses of Cambridgeand Sussexto dispel the long-standing rumours of a spat.Several weeks ago, it was also reported that the Duchess of Cambridge had fallen out with Rose Hanbury, one of her closest friends in the “Norfolk set”.The story has been dismissed as “unsubstantiated rumours” by sources within the Palace but it flared up again when Rose attended the recent Trump banquet without her husbandand was seated in practically a separate postcode to her old chum. Of course, they could kill those rumours stone dead too by being photographed together while out shopping or having lunch.That it hasn’t happened perhaps speaks volumes.AMAL CLOONEY is a well-regarded human rights lawyer who, together with husband George, uses her  to highlight ious liberal causes.So I was rather perplexed to hear – via a -page leaked document – that in  she reportedly gave legal advice to Wikileaks founder Julian Assange on how to potentially sabotage the British government’s bid to arrest him.Whether you think Assange’s role in leaking , classied US documents was espionage or heroism, it remains that he was also trying to avoid extradition to Sweden where he faced charges of sexual assault.How, pray tell, does that fit in with liberal values JENNIFER Lopez is  later this month and credits her youthfulness to daily “self-affirmations”.“I tell myself ‘I am youthful and timeless’ every day a few times a day,” she says. It sounds like cliched bull****, but it’s not. Age is all in your mind.”Hmmm. Quite frankly, I could chant her mantra on a loop and never look like this.One suspects that regular exercise, healthy eating and an expensive skincare regime have played their part too.A SMALL number of residents currently living in the swanky London area of Hampstead are up in arms at proposed boundary changes that would place their homes in nearby Gospel Oak.“By severing political ties, you’re disenfranchising many residents,” says one.What they actually mean is: The price of our houses will plummet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu ursula von der leyen brexit
story: Ursula von der Leyen narrowly squeaked into power in a secret ballot against no rival candidates in another triumph for European democracy.This unpopular, failed German defence minister is a fanatical federalist who longs for the Brussels club to become a single country made up of client states.“The world needs more Europe,” declared the new EU president, ly.Ursula is dead set too on a European army, with Eurocrats ordering national troops to war.Remember when Remainers sneered that was just a paranoid scare story told by Leavers Good luck to Ursula and her EU. She’s welcome to it — and to abusive clowns like vice-president Frans Timmermans who delights in mocking Britain.We can’t wait to be out.WE commend the Labour peers who have publicly denounced Corbyn for allowing their party to become a cesspit of racism.But there’s a problem. If a new Tory leader is forced into an early election, what will all these Lords and Ladies do We’ll bet good money that they and the “moderate” MPs apparently repulsed by anti-Semitism will campaign enthusiastically again for a Corbyn government.The reality is they will happily install a racist in Downing Street, to the terror of Britain’s Jews,he’s got a red rosette.If their concerns genuinely trumped everything, they’d have already found a way to boot out Corbyn and his lackeys — or left Labour, as others have.The anti-racism outrage has its limits, though, doesn’t it WHY is the Government letting the BBC dodge blame for the licence fee betrayal of the over-s  It’s time it pushed back.The funding deal they struck in  was clear enough: the free licences are expected to reach £million next year and the corporation would foot the bill from its huge £.billion annual bung.This overstuffed media empire, with its lavishly paid execs and celebrities, now says it cannot afford to without scrapping popular channels. If the Government won’t abolish this archaic licence, or at least decriminalise non-payment, it should axe the fee for OAPs . . .And strip the BBC of £million, by rewriting the long-term deal it welched on.WE have criticised Amber Rudd over Brexit.But we are delighted the Work and Pensions Secretary has listened to our Give Me Shelter and Make Universal Credit Work campaigns and acted.Credit where credit is due.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: its time we do more to save pubs
story: The Half Moon, in Kirdford, West Sussex, is one of three pubs where we used to hang out on a Friday night and the other two had already gone.Developers were snfing around to turn it into homes and once that happens there’s no chance of getting a pub back. The British boozer is in crisis.More than a quarter of all pubs have closed in the past two decades, from , in  to ,, according to the Office for National Statistics. We are losing three pubs a day. At this rate we will see the end of the British pub within our letime.So I got together with two friends who, like me, had never been in the licensed trade, to rescue this wonderful, warm, welcoming, Grade II listed building so everyone can continue to enjoy it. And I am not alone.I know of whole communities that have got together through crowd funding to save their local, with £.million being raised through internet donations for ious establishments last year.People are coming to realise that we can’t afford to lose these treasured spaces. There is no social network that can beat the pub, particularly in a world so insular where people have their noses in a mobile phone the whole time.It is so important people sit up and have a good chat, whether it is with a stranger at the bar or one of the staff. Workers come in after grafting and want to speak to the barmaid about what a hard day they’ve had, about the van breaking down or the tractor engine blowing up.Pubs often have football teams, darts, dominoes, quiz nights and are a venue where many great bands played their first gigs. In other places you will find a small shop at the local, because the village one has closed.At The Half Moon we sponsor the village cricket team, have Women’s Institute meetings with tea and cake in the morning, charity events and people come to celebrate weddings, birthdays and anniversaries.And no, nanny state meddlers, this isn’t about encouraging drinking, it’s about popping down to the local for a pint once or twice a week, which isn’t going to do any harm.The pub is now a place that families visit and I want everyone to treat it as their home.  My mum is in the garden, my dad helps out and my son Indio comes in to ask our head barman: “Can I have the usual please” — by which he means an apple juice and a packet of crisps.I had noticed pubs closing, but I hadn’t realised the reason until I became a landlady myself. Someone needs to give this industry a break. Landlords and land–ladies can only make tiny margins on the beer they sell, due to the high taxes they have to pay.That’s why I got involved with the Long Live The Local campaign last year to help pressure the Government into freezing beer duty. Everything is trying to kill this incredible part of British culture, whether it’s business rates, beer tax or sugar tax.Our rates are three times the European average and we pay almost  per cent of all beer duty across the EU, while drinking only  per cent of the beer. But the industry employs around , — many of them young people — and puts £BILLION into the economy.I can’t thank The Sun enough for its support in helping our campaign. I don’t think we would have received as many signatures without the help of you, the readers. Thankfully, the Chancellor listened to our case, agreeing in the last budget not to raise duty on beer.Sin taxes are high enough already and I hope the next Prime Minister will give us a break. It was an honour to be named  Beer Drinker Of The Year by the All-Party Parliamentary Beer Group, which promotes the unique role of the pub in our society.Certainly there is hope that this great institution can survive by changing with the times and adapting to new tastes.  It is amazing seeing all the microbreweries and gin distilleries starting up, with a new generation enthusiastic about real ingredients.The gastro pub movement also offers customers the quality food they desire. We were proud that our restaurant received two AA rosettes for culinary excellence in the first six months.But there is also a need for a pub to be a pub, where customers can come in with their wellies or work boots. At The Half Moon we have good dining on one side and an old-fashioned fireplace that drinkers can gather round on the other.For the first year I was there all the time, but now it’s wiping its own nose, so I go in two or three times a week — it’s my other jobs that pay the mortgage. It’s a great place to wind down, particularly on a Sunday, and it brings me a lot of joy.When I got the lease for the pub, a friend advised me to make sure I stood back once in a while to peer through the windows to see people having a good time. That’s why Britain’s pubs have to be saved.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bianca devins corpse photos stepmum
story: Distraught Kaleigh Nicole told of her horror at seeing grisly images of Bianca Devins body - which were shared by sickos on social media.One photo showing Bianca with her slit throat appeared on Instagram for a full  hours after it was posted by her alleged killer.Ms Nicole wrote on Facebook on Monday: It is absolutely disgusting that people are sharing, screenshoting the pictures of Bianca’sdeath!! Wtf is wrong with you people!!  I have seen the pictures.I will FOREVER have those images in my mind when I think of her.She added: When I close my eyes, those images haunt me.How about we have some f—ing consideration for her Mother, Sister, Step sisters and brother, Step Mother and Step Father, her Grandparents, Aunts, Uncles, Nieces and Newphews and her friends.How about we have some f***ing consideration FOR HER!!!”Bianca, , was found dead at home in Utica, upstate New York on Sunday.Her alleged killer Brandon Clark, , is accused of slashing the teens throat and posting a gruesome pic of the scene on Instagram with the message “sorry, police said.Hes then said to have repeatedly stabbed himself as police arrived.Clark allegedly posted more photos on other social media sites - including the image-sharing app Discord.He was taken to hospital in a critical condition and underwent emergency surgery.Clark remained there until the following day, when he was discharged and taken to the Oneida County Jail.Earlier, Clark allegedly posted a haunting video of himself driving along a dark road with the caption: Here comes Hell. Its redemption, right The images were still being circulated on other websites as late as Tuesday, according to Bryan Coromato of the Utica Police Department.Coromato said: “We reached out to [Instagram] as soon as we learned they were up there — it’s obvious it took about  hours to take down.“Those images are on s other than Instagram and they’re still being circulated.“Obviously this is heartbreaking for the family and the friends of the family — anybody that was close to her.We’re trying to work with the family and keep the exposure on the internet to a minimum.”Instagram allowed Clark’s account, @yesjuliet - where he posted a photo of Devins with a slashed throat - to stay active until Monday morning, according to the firm.A spokesman for Facebook, which owns Instagram, said: Our thoughts go out to those affected by this tragic event.We are taking every measure to remove this content from our s.Clark has been held on a charge of second-degree murder - but cops say more charges could follow.Police said Clark and Bianca had met online recently - and he is reported to have claimed to be her boyfriend.The two had attended a concert together the evening before the murder but argued on the way back.A statement by Utica police department read: “With respect to [Clark and Devins] relationship, it was learned that the two had met on the social media  Instagram approximately two months ago.They utilised this as a means of communication primarily, and their relationship progressed into a personally intimate one.They had spent time together, and were acquainted with each other’s families.”Clark is also reported to have uploaded an image of Devins to Discord, a messaging  for gamers, with the caption: Sorry f*****s, you’re gonna have to find somebody  to orbit.”Orbiting is a term used to describe men who follow women on social media in the hope of having sex with them.Bianca - who had , followers - had finished school last month and was preparing to go to community college this year.Her family described her as a talented artist and a wonderful young girl, taken from us all too so on.

title: mum claimed 113k benefits
story: Alison Christie Mains, , from Sydney, Australia made her first claim in  when she declared she was a single mother.Baby Tyler, who was disabled, died when she was just five months old.The offending began as a result of Ms Mains daughter dying in horric, tragic circumstances, aged five months, Marty Bernhaut, defending, said.He noted that at one point Mains distress over her child dying was so strong that she began “dressing up a doll and pretending it was her daughter”.It is unclear whether she dressed the doll up to pretend it was her daughter to collect benefits, orit was purely as a coping mechanism.Ms Mains arrived in court head to toe in black — with black leggings, T-shirt, shoes and with a black latex glove covering one hand.At several points she closed her eyes and breathed loudly and repetitively, rocking back and forth, as her solicitor spoke on her behalf to Judge Nicole Noman SC.She told Centrelink she was caring for her disabled daughter who was born with a serious neurological condition. However, her child had passed away more than a month previously.Defence counsel Martin Bernhaut said his client knew what she had done was wrong.“Ms Mains accepts that she received a range of payments relating to deceased child during a period when she was not entitled to.“She absolutely accepts that and she did make  representations to Centrelink that her child was alive and in her care and had ious disabilities that required additional care.”However, her solicitor added, the Judge should take into account that her daughter, “died in horric, tragic, circumstances aged five months”.The trauma of this together with her inability to read and write meant she was “never going to be able to work due to her range of conditions.”He noted that at one point her distress over her child dying was so strong that she began “dressing up a doll and pretending it was her daughter”.Mr Bernhaut said her “limited cognitive ability” meant she had been entitled to a range of other welfare payments which she didn’t claim.Ms Mains’ lawyer argued she potentially could have received around £, of Newstart allowance during the same period or nearly £, in disability support.The possible — but never claimed for — disability support payments would have added up to just £, less than she obtained for the care of her dead daughter.Ms Mains had a range of issues that included alcohol abuse and had spent several months in a residential hospital program to detox which her counsel asked to be taken into account in terms of sentencing.Mr Bernhaut said his client had already paid back around , of the funds.The sentencing was adjourned until  September.Similar offenses have happened in this country, including Karen Trant, , from Devon claimed she couldnt leave the house as she was an agoraphobic but snuck off to live in Goa for large parts of the year.She claimed £, in disability benefits, income support, housing benefit and council tax benefit.Ruth Nabaguzzi,  from Forest Gate in London cheated the taxpayer of an estimated £million using   identities.Pensioner Ian Burns, , from Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire swindled nearly £,, pretending to be three other people.

title: butlins 50s 60s vintage photos
story: A stunning collection of pictures of packed out Butlins holidays camps from the s and s have been unearthed.Holidaymakers can be seen packing out the pools, playing games in the clubhouse and whizzing around on four-wheel bikes.Ultra glamorous s pin-ups in their bikinis are pictured posing on ing boards and mucking around in a fountain.The images, which were recently discovered in TopFoto’s digital archives, show Butlins glory days when the camps soared in popularity.The firms original owner Billy Butlin wanted to make the British seaside break accessible to all, creating a place of colour and happiness where entertainment would be provided so that families could really enjoy their time together.Butlins started at a camp in Skegness in , followed by Clacton-on-Sea in .During World War Two the parks in Filey, Ayr, and Pwllheli were handed over to the government to help the war effort.Bognor Regis , Mineheadand Barry Islandopened next.The s saw foreign holidays become increasingly affordable and British staycations lost their allure.The Butlin family sold the business to the Rank Organisation in  for £million, before it was bought by Bourne Leisure in .Today the company is investing heavily in its three remaining sites in Skegness, Bognor and Minehead.

title: razor screwdriver 33 items removed mans belly
story: Yogesh Thakur, , was admitted to hospital in central India on Sunday after complaining of severe abdominal pain.Medics decided to carry out an X-ray and were shocked to discover dozens of sharp objects, such as a kne, inside his stomach.Surgery was carried out two days later and Mr Thakur, a part-time farmer, is expected to be discharged in the next few days.His mother, Kusma Thakur, said: He grabs anything and eats it. But we were surprised when we came to know that he could eat such dangerous things too.Dr MPN Khare, who performed the operation, said that Yogesh suffered from altered mental status , a general term used to describe ious disorders of mental ing that can range from slight confusion to coma.He said: “It was a rather dficult surgery as he suffered from hypertension.We were shocked and surprised to find over thirty sharp objects inside his abdomen.The man is believed to suffer from a rare disorder known as acuphagia, where people eat sharp metal objects and other indigestible items.Acuphagia is the term used to describe eating sharp objects.Its a sub-type of pica syndrome - an eating behaviour in which iniduals eat non-nutritive items or substances, according to Psychology Today.Sufferers can have the urge to consume all matter of objects, from coins, to clothes, to cigarette butts.Although very few cases of acuphagia have been reported in the medical literature, particularly in adults, most of these suggest that those displaying the symptoms have psychological and or psychiatric disorders that may be accompanied by some form of learning disability.While the NHS doesn’t outline specic treatment for pica, they do recommend dferent options from those battling eating disorders.Cognitive behavioural therapy can be useful for altering the way a patient thinks about a situation, which can help change the way they act.Interpersonal psychotherapy, which involves talking about the disorder to an expert, can also be helpful.Dietary counselling and cognitive analytic therapy are among the other options available.If you have pica syndrome, it’s advisable to visit your local GP to discuss treatment options.Its a form of pica - a psychological disorder characterised by an appetite for substances that are largely non-nutritive, such as ice, hair, paper, drywall or paint, sharp objects, metal, stones, soil, glass, faeces and chalk.Usually, it occurs alongside mental health conditions that impair , such as autism or schizophrenia.The prevalence of pica is not known but it is believed to be more common in developing countries, according to the National Eating Disorders Associations.Its not the first time such a strange instance has occurred in India.A man in the north-west Indian state of Rajasthan, who swallowed  nails, underwent a successful operation in May this year.In another incident, surgeons removed around three pounds of metals including nuts, bolts and jewellery from a womans stomach in the western Indian state of Gujarat last year.

title: heatwave america temperature weather
story: Washington D.C will be just two degrees shy of the scorching temperatures in the Death Valley desert in Calornia.The dangerous heat is set to break more than  local heat records and experts warn it wont even cool down overnight.Officials have released warnings that smog may make it more dficult for certain people to breathe - including the very young, elderly and those with asthma or lung diseases.For most areas, it wont be record-breaking daily highs, but more that it wont cool down during the night - which can be dangerous.Washingtons Mayor Muriel Bowser declared a heat emergency on Tuesday.Today, Philadelphia and New York have followed suit.New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said: Extreme heat is dangerous, period.We are deploying all resources at our disposal to ensure New Yorkers remain safe and cool during extreme heat.”For today and tomorrow, parts of Texas, Oklahoma and parts of the Midwest will feel the burn, and on Saturday its expected to spread east to Maine and Florida.Temperatures in parts of the East wont drop below C at night.At this level, temperatures will be - degrees above average even for the middle of the summer.The heatwave will likely be short and searing said Greg Carbin, forecast branch chief for the weather services Weather Prediction Center.The heat index, which is what the temperature feels like, should hit in Washington, D.C., on Saturday and in Chicago and Detroit on Friday, said Jeff Masters, meteorology director of Weather Underground.According to Current Results, the typical temperature for most of the US is between  and  degrees.Yesterday it was Washington D.Cs seventh day of temperatures of at least C and it is expected to last another five days.According to AccuWeather, Washington will feel as hot as Death Valley on Saturday.In the nations capital, the temperatures are forecast to reach c, just  degrees less than the Calornian desert.Fire stations in Detroit will be open around the clock, and in Chicago the police station will be its primary -hour cooling centre.For animals the weather is expected to be incredibly tough, with staff at Brookfield Zoo near Chicago preparing by ordering huge blocks of ice.In New York at least one person has died after remnants of Tropical Storm Barry hit, with dramatic scenes of lightning and water gushing through subway stations.Jarrod Marotto, , from Connecticut, died after a tree was struck by lightning and a large branch fell onto his car.He died on the way to the hospital, according to WABC-TV.

title: brit parents take family holiday same place kids
story: Research shows parent are keen to reveal their families connections to their children.A survey from Ancestry revealed more than a quarter of people are likely to visit places they saw in old family photos.And even more admitted that visiting a place where an ancestor lived would add something special to a trip. Brits consider themselves “well-travelled” – visiting an average  countries in their letime and going overseas twice a year, but holidays to places connected with our own personal history are central to the nation’s travel choices.Lisa Francesca Nand, host of the chart-topping Big Travel Podcast, said: “Holidays connected with our own personal history are so popular – largely due to nostalgia and family tradition.Our own parents chose these destinations for a reason they’re generally good value, warm, friendly and offer plenty of activities for children happy kids equal happy parents.Although more families are travelling further and wider than ever, carrying on special traditions, such as building sandcastles on the beach or going on long walks together hold sentimental value generation after generation.The research comes as % of Brits say they would love to visit the places where their ancestors called homethey knew where it was.Russell James, DNA and Family History expert at Ancestry, said: “It’s no surprise that the staycation trend is continuing to grow but it’s interesting to see that an increasing appetite for people to understand where their relatives are from or lived is evolving how we travel the UK.Combining holidays and family history can be very rewarding – you can take your children to the same beach your parents visited when they were children, or drive down the same streets your grandparents lived.These personal, unique experiences can be made possible and more accurate by Ancestry’s database of over  million DNA customers, and our billions of global digitalised record collections.The combination of these tools can bring your DNA and family history closer together than ever before, and inspire your next staycation.”
